maml:description.maml:para: Adds a new Azure Resource Manager service endpoint.
The cmdlet adds a new connection between TFS/VSTS and Azure using the Azure Resource Manager connection type.

maml:Description.maml:para: The display name of the service endpoint.
Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.
The id of the Azure subscription to use.
The id of the Azure tenant to use.
The name displayed on the services page. In VSTS this is the Connection Name.
The display name of the service endpoint.
The id of the Azure subscription to use.
The id of the Azure tenant to use.
The name displayed on the services page. In VSTS this is the Connection Name.
Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.

maml:alert.maml:para: ## RELATED LINKS

maml:description.maml:para: Queues a new build.
Add-Build will queue a new build.
You can override the queue in the build defintion by using the QueueName parameter.
To have the BuildDefinition and QueueNames tab complete you must set a default project by calling Set-DefaultProject before you call Add-Build.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.
The name of the build defintion to use to queue to build.
The name of the queue to use for this build.
Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.
The name of the queue to use for this build.
The Id of the build defintion to use to queue to build.
Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.
The name of the build defintion to use to queue to build.
The name of the queue to use for this build.
The Id of the build defintion to use to queue to build.

maml:description.maml:para: Build Defintion Name
Queue Name

maml:alert.maml:para: BuildDefinition and QueueName are dynamic parameters and use the default project value to query their validate set.
If you do not set the default project by called Set-DefaultProject before calling Add-Build you will have to type in the names.
## RELATED LINKS

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Set-DefaultProject Demo PS C:\> Add-Build -BuildDefinition Demo-CI
Build Definition Build Number Status Result ---------------- ------------ ------ ------ Demo-CI Demo-CI-45 notStarted

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the default project so you can tab complete the BuildDefinition parameter.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new build defintion from a JSON file.

Specifies the team project for which this function operates.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a Team Project to your Team Services account.
This will create a new Team Project in your Team Foundation Server or Team Services account.

This will add a project name MyProject with no description using the Agile process template and TFVC source control.

maml:description.maml:para: Queues a new release
Add-Release will queue a new release.
The environments will deploy according to how the release definition is configured in the Triggers tab.
You must call Add-TeamAccount before calling this function.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.
The id of the release defintion to use.
The description to use on the release.
The alias of the artifact to use with this release.
The name of this release.
The id of the build to use with this release.
The branch of the artifact

The number of the build to use.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function has a Dynamic Parameter for ProjectName that specifies the project for which this function gets release s.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-Build | ft id,name
id name -- ---- 44 Demo-CI-44
PS C:\> Get-ReleaseDefinition -Expand artifacts | ft id,name,@{l='Alias';e={$_.artifacts[0].alias}}
id name Alias -- ---- ----- 1 Demo-CD Demo-CI
PS C:\> Add-Release -DefinitionId 1 -Description Test -ArtifactAlias Demo-CI -BuildId 44

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to find the Build ID, Artifact Alias, and Release Defintion ID required to start a release. If you call Set-DefaultProject you can use Example 2 which is much easier.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-Release -DefinitionName Demo-CD -Description Test -BuildNumber Demo-CI-44

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command starts a new release using the Demo-CD release defintion and the build with build number Demo-CI-44.
You must set a default project to tab complete DefinitionName and BuildNumber.

maml:description.maml:para: Starts the deployment of an environment in an existing release.
Add-ReleaseEnvironment will start the deployment of an environment within an existing release.
You must call Add-TeamAccount before calling this function.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.
Forces the command without confirmation
Specifies the Id of an existing Release in which you want to deploy to a particular environment.
Specifies the Id of the Environment you wish to deploy to. The Environment Ids are unique for each environment and in each release.
Specifies the status in which to set the environment. The deployment of an environment is triggered by changing the status of the environment.
The currently supported status change is from 'notStarted' to 'inProgress'
Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.

The currently supported status change is from 'notStarted' to 'inProgress'

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a new SonarQube service endpoint.
The cmdlet adds a new connection between TFS/VSTS and a SonarQube server using the SonarQube connection type.
This is only used when using the SonarQube tasks.
Using SonarQube with the Maven tasks uses a Generic Connection type.

Authentication Token generated by SonarQube.

maml:description.maml:para: Stores your account name and personal access token for use with the other functions in this module.
On Windows you have to option to store the information at the process, user or machine (you must be running PowerShell as administrator to store at the machine level) level.
On Linux and Mac you can only store at the process level.
Calling Add-TeamAccount will clear any default project.

maml:Description.maml:para: The Visual Studio Team Services (VSTS) account name to use. DO NOT enter the entire URL.

Just the portion before visualstudio.com. For example in the following url mydemos is the account name. https://mydemos.visualstudio.com or The full Team Foundation Server (TFS) url including the collection. http://localhost:8080/tfs/DefaultCollection
A secured string to capture your personal access token. This will allow you to provide your personal access token without displaying it in plain text.
To use pat simply omit it from the Add-TeamAccount command.
The Visual Studio Team Services (VSTS) account name to use. DO NOT enter the entire URL.

Just the portion before visualstudio.com. For example in the following url mydemos is the account name. https://mydemos.visualstudio.com or The full Team Foundation Server (TFS) url including the collection. http://localhost:8080/tfs/DefaultCollection
The personal access token from VSTS/TFS to use to access this account.
The Visual Studio Team Services (VSTS) account name to use. DO NOT enter the entire URL.

Just the portion before visualstudio.com. For example in the following url mydemos is the account name. https://mydemos.visualstudio.com or The full Team Foundation Server (TFS) url including the collection. http://localhost:8080/tfs/DefaultCollection
Allows the use of the current user's Windows credentials to authenticate against a local TFS.

On Windows allows you to store your account information at the Process, User or Machine levels. When saved at the User or Machine level your account information will be in any future PowerShell processes.

On Windows allows you to store your account information at the Process, User or Machine levels. When saved at the User or Machine level your account information will be in any future PowerShell processes.
The Visual Studio Team Services (VSTS) account name to use. DO NOT enter the entire URL.

Just the portion before visualstudio.com. For example in the following url mydemos is the account name. https://mydemos.visualstudio.com or The full Team Foundation Server (TFS) url including the collection. http://localhost:8080/tfs/DefaultCollection
A secured string to capture your personal access token. This will allow you to provide your personal access token without displaying it in plain text.
To use pat simply omit it from the Add-TeamAccount command.

On Windows allows you to store your account information at the Process, User or Machine levels. When saved at the User or Machine level your account information will be in any future PowerShell processes.
The personal access token from VSTS/TFS to use to access this account.
Allows the use of the current user's Windows credentials to authenticate against a local TFS.

dev:remarks.maml:para: You will be prompted for the account name and personal access token.
Allows you to provide all the information on the command line.
On Windows, allows you use to use Windows authentication against a local TFS server.

maml:description.maml:para: Clears the value stored in the default project parameter value.
Clears the value stored in the default project parameter value.

maml:Description.maml:para: On Windows allows you to clear your default project at the Process, User or Machine levels.
On Windows allows you to clear your default project at the Process, User or Machine levels.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will clear the default project parameter value. You will now have to provide a project for any functions that require a project.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a list of approvals for all releases for a team project.
The Get-Approval function gets the approvals for all releases for a team project.
With just a project name, this function gets all of the pending approvals for that team project.
The Team.Approval type has three custom table formats:
Pending: ID, Status, Release Name, Environment, Type, Approver Name, Release Definitions
Approved: Release Name, Environment, Is Automated, Approval Type, Approver Name, Release Definitions, Comments
Rejected: Release Name, Environment, Approval Type, Approver Name, Release Definition, Comments

maml:Description.maml:para: By default the function returns Pending approvals.
Using this filter you can return Approved, ReAssigned or Rejected approvals.
There is a custom table view for each status.
Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.
Only approvals for the release ids provided will be returned.
Approvals are filtered to only those assigned to this user.
By default the function returns Pending approvals.
Using this filter you can return Approved, ReAssigned or Rejected approvals.
There is a custom table view for each status.
Only approvals for the release ids provided will be returned.
Approvals are filtered to only those assigned to this user.
Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.

dev:type.maml:name: You can pipe build defintion IDs to this function.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function has a Dynamic Parameter for ProjectName that specifies the project for which this function gets build definitions.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a list of all pending approvals.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-Approval -ProjectName Demo -StatusFilter Approved | Format-Table -View Approved

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a list of all approved approvals using a custom table format.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-Approval -ProjectName Demo -AssignedToFilter Administrator -StatusFilter Rejected | FT -View Rejected

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a list of all approvals rejected by Administrator using a custom table format.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the builds for a team project.
The Get-Build function gets the builds for a team project.
With just a project name, this function gets all of the builds for that team project.
You can also specify a particular build by ID.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the team project for which this function operates.
You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.
Specifies the maximum number to return.
Specifies the result of the builds to return Succeeded, PartiallySucceeded, Failed, or Canceled.
Specifies the reason the build was created of the builds to return Manual, IndividualCI, BatchedCI, Schedule, UserCreated, ValidateShelveset, CheckInShelveset, Triggered, or All.
Specifies the status of the builds to return InProgress, Completed, Cancelling, Postponed, NotStarted, or All.
A comma-delimited list of queue IDs that specifies the builds to return.
A comma-delimited list of build definition IDs that specifies the builds to return.
Returns the build with this build number.
You can also use * for a starts with search i.e. 2015* will return all build numbers that start with 2015.
The type of builds to retrieve.
The maximum number of builds to retrieve for each definition.
This is only valid when definitions is also specified.
A comma-delimited list of extended properties to retrieve.
Specifies one or more builds by ID.
To specify multiple IDs, use commas to separate the IDs.
To find the ID of a build, type Get-Build.
Specifies the maximum number to return.
Specifies the result of the builds to return Succeeded, PartiallySucceeded, Failed, or Canceled.

Specifies the status of the builds to return InProgress, Completed, Cancelling, Postponed, NotStarted, or All.
A comma-delimited list of queue IDs that specifies the builds to return.
A comma-delimited list of build definition IDs that specifies the builds to return.
Returns the build with this build number.
You can also use * for a starts with search i.e. 2015* will return all build numbers that start with 2015.

This is only valid when definitions is also specified.

Specifies one or more builds by ID.
To specify multiple IDs, use commas to separate the IDs.
To find the ID of a build, type Get-Build.

If not specified, all types will be returned.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns a list of projects in the Team Services or Team Foundation Server account.

You can also get a single project by name or id.
You must call Add-TeamAccount before calling this function.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the releases for a team project.
The Get-Release function gets the releases for a team project.
The project name is a Dynamic Parameter which may not be displayed in the syntax above but is mandatory.

You can also specify a particular release defintion by ID.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns all the versions of supported APIs of your TFS or VSTS.
Returns all the versions of supported APIs of your TFS or VSTS. There are two table formats defined for the Team.Option type, Default and Versions.
Default view contains Name, Area, Max Version and URI Template.
Version view contains Name, Area, Min Version, Max Version, Released Version and Resource Version.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the default project to be used with other calls in the module.
The majority of the functions in this module require a project name.
By setting a default project you can omit that parameter from your function calls and this default will be used instead.

You can tab complete from a list of available projects.
You can use Set-DefaultProject to set a default project so you do not have to pass the ProjectName with each call.
Forces the command without confirmation
On Windows allows you to store your default project at the Process, User or Machine levels.
When saved at the User or Machine level your default project will be in any future PowerShell processes.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the name of your project from Demo to aspDemo.
